Donald Trump betrayed America’s foundational values by slashing our annual refugee admissions to 30,000. That’s why I introduced the GRACE Act, which will prohibit any president from setting an annual ceiling below the historic average of 95,000 refugee admissions.

For the first time since 1980, Canada resettled more refugees than the U.S. With more than 24 million refugees around the globe and 70 million displaced persons, America must step into our leadership role, not away from it. https://www.cnn.com/2019/06/19/americas/canada-us-refugee-resettlement-hnk-intl/index.html …

More often than not, we have answered that call — and today, it sounds to us louder than ever. But after centuries of opening our door to the persecuted, the Trump administration has forsaken our historic commitment to the world’s most vulnerable.

The first settlers fleeing religious oppression. Irish Catholics fleeing starvation. Eastern European Jews fleeing the pogroms. Syrians fleeing civil war. At nearly every juncture since its founding, America has been called upon to be a leader in welcoming the persecuted.

On #WorldRefugeeDay, we keep in our hearts the millions of refugees around the globe who, despite facing devastating circumstances, display remarkable strength every day as they seek refuge for themselves and their loved ones.

Alysia’s op-ed alerted me to this issue and I wrote to @TeamUSA with @SenatorBaldwin and @SenBlumenthal to demand an explanation. USOC said they plan on addressing this and I intend to ensure they follow through. Alysia isn’t just a world champion, she’s a champion for justice.

The U.S. Olympic Committee has a policy of taking away an athlete’s health insurance when they get pregnant. Getting pregnant shouldn’t be a “kiss of death for a female athlete.” @AlysiaMontano courageously exposed this discrimination: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/12/opinion/nike-maternity-leave.html …

Our courtrooms are supposed to be chambers of justice, not hate. So-called gay and trans panic defenses perpetuate bigotry and violence toward the LGBTQ community, blame victims for the violence committed against them, and must be banned. https://www.advocate.com/politics/2019/6/05/bill-congress-would-ban-gay-trans-panic-defenses …

All Americans deserve to be treated with dignity and humanity in our justice system. As we celebrate Pride Month, I call on my colleagues to support this bill and relegate the hateful practice of gay and trans panic defense to the history books.

Gay and trans panic defenses shamefully are still allowed in 46 states. Unless you live in IL/CA/NV/RI, they could be used in a case in your state. This bill can serve as a model for other states to begin banning homophobia/biphobia/transphobia from the courtroom.

(via @lgbtmap) pic.twitter.com/ndKFp9lXm1

So-called “gay and trans panic” defenses can excuse violent crimes by blaming a victim’s sexual orientation or gender identity for a defendant’s attack. @RepJoeKennedy and I have introduced legislation to ban the use of these hateful defenses in all federal courts. pic.twitter.com/kmyTu5CxvJ

Residents of the Berkshires deserve access to local broadcast television stations. Charter’s consumers shouldn’t be caught in the middle of this business dispute. Congress should pass legislation that I introduced with Senators Rubio, Kaine, and Young to mandate disclosures of all 810 authorizations, and I reiterate my call for the Trump administration to suspend all civil nuclear cooperation with Saudi Arabia indefinitely.

America should not be sharing nuclear tech with Saudi Arabia, which openly declared willingness to pursue nuclear weapons. The only reason the Trump admin withheld this information for so long was to hide what it was doing & escape Congressional oversight. https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/trump-admin-gave-green-light-nuclear-permits-saudi-arabia-after-n1013826 …

100 years ago, the Senate passed the 19th Amendment giving women the right to vote. As the suffragists knew, rights aren’t guaranteed. They are fought for, won, and defended. Today, we celebrate their example of courage and strength by vowing to never stop fighting for equality.
